{{Infobox Military Structure |name=Fortín Solano |partof= |location=[[Puerto Cabello]], [[Carabobo]] |map_type= |map_alt= |latitude=10.4625 |longitude=-68.016667 |coordinates = |open_to_public = yes |controlledby = State government |type = [[Fortress]] |condition = |materials = |built = {{circa|{{Start date|1766}}}} |image= [[File:Fortin Solano 2003 000derv.jpg|250px]] |caption= Fortín Solano was built at the top of the Cresta de Vigía (or "lookout crest") to protect the city from naval attacks. }} '''Fortín Solano''' is an eighteenth-century colonial fortification overlooking [[Puerto Cabello]], [[Venezuela]]. With the [[San Felipe Castle|Castillo San Felipe]], an earlier fort built at sea level, it formed part of a complex of fortifications designed to protect Puerto Cabello and its important harbour from naval attacks. It was constructed {{circa|1766}} by order of Don [[José Solano y Bote]] on behalf of the [[Charles III of Spain|King of Spain]]. It has been described as the last military construction built in Venezuela during the colonial era.
The fort has been the center of several notable events in [[History of Venezuela|Venezuelan history]]. Spanish commander [[Antonio Zuazola]] was hanged after a surprise attack by the forces of [[Rafael Urdaneta]] overthrew the royalists, giving control of the fort to the patriots. [[Pedro Carujo]] was imprisoned in the fort after attempting to kill [[Simón Bolívar]] in 1828. In 1962, the fort was the stronghold of an uprising led by several commanders in the city.
It was declared [[National monument]] in 1965 and is located inside the [[San Esteban National Park]], which was designed in 1987.
==Description== Fortín Solano is located in the [[San Esteban National Park]], south of [[Puerto Cabello]], [[Carabobo]]. It is a military fort built by order of governor of Venezuela, Don [[José Solano y Bote]] {{circa|1766}} in the area referred to as Cresta de Vigía (or "lookout crest"). It was designed to house [[Artillery battery|artillery]] and was intended to protect the commercial complex of the city<ref>{{cite book|last=López Villa|first=Manuel Antonio|title=Arquitectura e historia: curso de historia de la arquitectura|year=2003|publisher=Consejo de Desarrollo Científico y Humanístico. [[Universidad Central de Venezuela]]|location=Caracas|isbn=9789800020739|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-ZTYuVIgBtQC&pg=PA567|accessdate=5 January 2013|page=567|language=Spanish|volume=2}}</ref> and the harbour from naval attacks.<ref name=Tuya>{{cite web|title=Fortín Solano|url=http://www.venezuelatuya.com/natura/fortin_solano.htm|publisher=Venezuela Tuya|accessdate=5 January 2013|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6DS0OPNuP|archivedate=5 January 2013|language=Spanish}}</ref> It was the only colonial fortification to be built between 1763 and 1771<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HUQTAQAAIAAJ|last=Núñez Pérez|first=Luis|title=Guía del Estado Carabobo|year=2003|location=Valencia|edition=7|accessdate=5 January 2013|page=99|language=Spanish}}</ref> and it is described as the last military construction built during the colonial era in Venezuela.<ref name=Notitarte>{{cite web|title=Fortín Solano: Altas murallas, baluarte histórico de Puerto Cabello|url=http://www.notitarde.com/La%20Costa/Fort%C3%ADn-Solano-Altas-murallas-baluarte-hist%C3%B3rico-de-Puerto-Cabello/2012/08/20/127115|publisher=Notitarde|accessdate=5 January 2013}}</ref>
==History==
===Eighteenth and nineteenth centuries=== [[File:Fortinpuertocabello.jpg|thumb|Fortín Solano]]
Before the construction of Fortín Solano, Puerto Cabello had resisted attacks from the British in the [[Battle of Puerto Cabello]]. Puerto Cabello continued to be controlled by Spanish forces after the fort's construction in 1766 until it was lost to Venezuela patriots on September 1, 1813. A surprise attack took place, aided by the forces of [[Rafael Urdaneta]],<ref name="Boletin">{{cite book|title=Boletín de historia y antigüedades|year=1975|publisher=Imprenta Nacional|accessdate=5 January 2013|page=16|language=Spanish|volume=62|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2X81AAAAIAAJ}}</ref> in the midst of the [[Admirable Campaign]] in the [[Venezuelan War of Independence]].<ref name="Fuentes-Figueroa">{{cite book|last=Fuentes-Figueroa Rodríguez|first=Julián|title=La Segunda República de Venezuela(18 12-1814)|year=2003|publisher=Ediciones de la Presidencia de la República|isbn=9789800303306|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NFVsAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=5 January 2013|page=78|language=Spanish}}</ref> The following day, Spanish commander Antonio Zuazola, who was known for having mutilated hundreds of prisoners in the east of the country, was imprisoned.<ref>{{cite book|last=Romero Luengo|first=Adolfo|title=Presencia vital de Urdaneta en la emancipación y en el gobierno de Colombia la Grande|year=1981|publisher=Ediciones de la Presidencia de la República|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gQEYAAAAYAAJ|edition=2|accessdate=5 January 2013|page=347|language=Spanish}}</ref> [[Simón Bolívar]], leader of the patriots, offered [[Domingo de Monteverde]], leader of the royalists, the exchange of Zuazola with Domingo Jalón.<ref>{{cite book|last=Peña Vásquez|first=Salvador|title=Drama de honor|year=1981|publisher=Sucesores de Rivadeneyra|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rXFKAAAAYAAJ|edition=2|page=243|language=Spanish|accessdate=5 January 2013}}</ref> After the proposal was rejected by the royalists, Bolívar ordered the death of Zuazola, who was hanged from a flagpole outside the walls of the fort.<ref>{{cite book|last=Montilla|first=José Abel|title=Fermin Entrena, un venezolano del noventa y nueve: novela historica|year=1988|publisher=Biblioteca de Autores y Temas Tachirenses|edition=2|accessdate=5 January 2013|page=426|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Martínez|first=Alí Brett|title=El Porteñazo: historia de una rebelión|year=1973|publisher=Adaro|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V9Q3AQAAIAAJ|edition=2|accessdate=5 January 2013|page=23|language=Spanish}}</ref>
In 1828, Bolívar issued a decree establishing his dictatorship in the country; as a result, a group of young lawyers gathered to depose Bolívar and proclaim [[Francisco de Paula Santander]] as constitutional president. On the night of September 25, 1828 the conspirators attempted to assassinate Bolivar at the presidential palace; Bolívar managed to escape with the help of [[Manuela Sáenz]] by jumping from a window until the military forces restored control of the city.<ref>{{cite web|title=Conspiración septembrina|url=http://www.banrepcultural.org/node/45618|work=Biblioteca Virtual Luis Angel Arango|publisher=Banco de la República|accessdate=5 January 2013|language=Spanish}}</ref> [[Pedro Carujo]], born in [[Barcelona, Anzoátegui|Barcelona]], became a Commander in 1828, hand picked by Simón Bolívar to lead the Military Academy founded in Bogotá. However, Carujo joined the supporters of Santander and attempted to kill Bolívar while on the revolt of September 25, for which he was sentenced to death and moved to the Solano fort in March 1829. After managing to escape several months later, he was recaptured and irons were attached to him. He was deported to [[Curacao]] in June 1830, only to return several months later under the government of [[José Antonio Páez]].<ref name=Carujo>{{cite web|title=Pedro Carujo|url=http://www.venezuelatuya.com/biografias/carujo.htm|publisher=Venezuela Tuya|accessdate=5 January 2013}}</ref>
===Twentieth century=== In 1904, a budget designed by engineer Germán Jimenez was approved by the Ministry of Public Works to repair the fort.<ref>{{cite book|title=Recopilacion de leyes y decretos de Venezuela|year=1905|publisher=La Opinion Nacional|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3u4wAAAAIAAJ|accessdate=5 January 2013|page=468|language=Spanish|volume=27}}</ref>
On June 2, 1962 an uprising (the [[Porteñazo]]) led by Manuel Ponte Rodriguez, commander Pedro Medina Silva and Lieutenant Commander Victor Hugo Morales occurred in the city of Puerto Cabello. As soon as the national Government became aware of the revolt, troops of both the Air Force and the Army led by Colonel Alfredo Monch are sent to bomb and surround the city. At the same time, most of the officers in command of 55th National Guard squadron and detachment refuse to participate in the uprising.<ref name=porte>{{cite web|title=El Carupanazo y El Porteñazo|url=http://www.venezuelatuya.com/historia/carupanazo_portenazo.htm|publisher=Venezuela Tuya|accessdate=5 January 2013}}</ref> The following day, the Ministry of Interior announced that Armed forces loyal to the government defeated the rebellion with a balance of 400 deaths and 700 wounded.<ref name=porte/> On June 6, Fortín Solano, which was used as a stronghold by the rebels, fell when the leaders of the revolt were captured by the Army.<ref name=porte/>
===Conservation=== The fort was declared a [[National monument]] in 1965.<ref name=Notitarte/> {{clear}} It is included in the boundaries of a National Park which, as well as being of ecological importance, protects other infrastructure dating from the colonial era, including the ''Camino de los Españoles'', a route to Valencia.
